title: How to Manage a Balcony Garden

steps.headline: Check with your property manager what the rules for your building are.
steps.description: Some buildings do not allow you to have any plants (or anything else for that matter) stored on the balcony. It’s also a nice courtesy to ask your neighbors if they are ok with you growing a balcony garden. If you don’t comply with these rules, you may end up receiving a fine or some other punishment. Not having your landlord or property manager on your side is definitely something you want to avoid so this is really important. Make sure any permission is in writing so you have real evidence rather than just a verbal agreement.

steps.headline: Measure out the area you have to work with.
steps.description: If you decide that you want a balcony garden, it’s very easy to run to the nearest plant store and buy everything in sight. Any creative project is exciting! However, the last thing you want is to buy far too many plants and then realize you don’t have room for all of them! Remember, when you are measuring, that you probably don’t want plants to cover your entire balcony so work conservatively to the space you have. Using buckets or plates to act as indicators of how large a garden pot will be is a good idea here.

steps.headline: Make sure your balcony has a drainage system.
steps.description: Water-logging plants is one of the fastest ways to kill them and you need to make sure that your balcony drains properly. If you are new into your apartment, you may never have seen how the building responds in a downpour. Your balcony should have a drainage hole in it as well as some kind of slope toward this hole. If it does not, check with your property manager about how the drainage system works. If you live in a particularly arid or dry climate then this may not be much of an issue for you to worry about.

steps.headline: Research what kind of plants you’ll be able to grow in your climate.
steps.description: There are several factors included in this. The main ones are how much space the plants will need, and what kind of weather conditions they can grow in. Weather is something you have no control over so, for example, buying a plant that can’t handle any rain when you know you live in a rainy climate is pointless, as it will die quickly. Some plants start small and grow to be very large, others start large and don’t grow at all. When you buy plants, make sure you check with a store-clerk or the information section to see how large the plant will grow to be and that your balcony can handle that size. A couple of different plants to try might be Oleanders for areas with high wind and lots of sun, or Red-leaf bananas for less light and less wind.

steps.headline: Buy climbing plants to maximise the space.
steps.description:
One easy way to create a stunning visual effect on your balcony is to grow climbing plants. Not only do they use a different spatial effect, but they look fantastic, can completely change the dynamic of your garden, and often grow well in shady climates. Some of these plants are:
Ivy
Passionflower
Jasmine

steps.headline: Try planting vegetables in addition to regular plants.
steps.description:
Contrary to popular belief, vegetables actually make fantastic balcony plants. Lots of vegetables grow really well in pots which makes them ideal for growing on balconies. Some of the best vegetables to grow on balconies are:
Tomatoes
Lettuces
Radishes
Beans

steps.headline: Buy some gardening tools.
steps.description:
If you’ve never had a garden before, you may not have the necessary tools to maintain it. They are very easy to find at any regular home improvement or home goods store. Some of these tools might be:
Watering pot
Pruning shears
Garden fork and scoop

steps.headline: Make sure that you have enough time to maintain the garden.
steps.description: Unfortunately, balcony gardens aren’t things that you can simply ignore and also see flourish. They require about an hour of attention each week (depending on size) to make sure the plants are healthy, well-watered, and pruned. There’s no point in creating a garden if you just don’t have the time to devote to it. If you live with anyone else, set up a schedule of various garden duties to help make it easier on yourself.

steps.headline: Arrange your plants so they receive enough sunlight.
steps.description:
Plants have a variety of sunlight needs. Some require very little natural light and others require large amounts. Depending on the types of plants you have, you may have to arrange the plants in a certain way to allow all plants to get their necessary light. A few of the plants you can grow in shady or no-light balconies include:
Dracaena
Bromeliads
Maidenhair Fern	EXPERT TIP																															Chai Saechao																Founder, Plant Therapy								Chai Saechao is the Founder and Owner of Plant Therapy, an indoor-plant store founded in 2018 based in San Francisco, California. As a self-described plant doctor, he believes in the therapeutic power of plants, hoping to keep sharing his love of plants with anyone willing to listen and learn. Chai Saechao			Founder, Plant Therapy				Opt for durable plants for a balcony garden. Founder of Plant Therapy Chai Saechao says: "In general we don't encourage placing plants on a balcony. However, if you really want a balcony garden, look for cacti or succulents that will do well outside in the shade. Birds of paradise and yucca will also do well because they're very durable."

steps.headline: Place the plants in a safe location away from any ledges.
steps.description: When plants are located outside, they have to endure any weather you experience. This obviously includes wind. Many plants that are the right size for a balcony are also small enough to get blown over by a strong gust of wind. If a plant is near a ledge and it gets blown over by wind or some other force, there is a huge falling risk to any person or thing that may be below it. If you do happen to store your plants above solid ground in any way, they should be securely fastened in and well supported.

steps.headline: Use an organic spray to help with pest control.
steps.description: Once your garden is flowering nicely, it’s likely that you will encounter pests attempting to eat and destroy your garden. If you are encountering caterpillars and other pests, using an organic salt spray, mineral oil, or garlic spray will help keep them at bay. Many insects such as ladybugs, bees, and dragonflies are actually necessary for your garden so don't panic if you see these buzzing around.

steps.headline: Postpone the arrival of winter with a bed-sheet or other cover.
steps.description: Throwing a bed-sheet over your plants at the start of winter can prolong the growth of flowers. However, winter will naturally bring an end to growth of many plants. You can leave root vegetables in the garden through winter as well as many perennials herbs such as sage and thyme. Some plants, such as geraniums, you will simply have to bring inside if you want growth to continue through winter. Do your research on how winter-proof your plants are and prepare accordingly.
